Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 07:26PM - edited Sep 17, 2010 07:28PM by Halah Thanks guys. Looks like a grade 1. I don't know why it is so difficult to find the answers through the medical professionals I deal with. My surgeon acted like I was using language (i.e., grade) that is used only on this site. Obviously it is used on the American Cancer Society's site and elsewhere and not just here.  Thanks again.
Posts.Title: What is the grade of my tumor? Halah lago

Posts.Content: Halah wrote: (Cancer.org is American Cancer Society.) I am trying to understand my pathology report as it relates to the grade of my IDC tumor. My BS says it is intermediate (I question this because it is expressed differently on cancer.org than in the report which uses the "Nottingham Histological Score" not mentioned on cancer.org). I am comparing my report to what I am reading on cancer.org's page on "How is breast cancer diagnosed". This is what my report says: HistologicGrade Invasive Carcinoma (Nottingham Histologic Score):*Tubule formation: 1 *Nuclear grade: 2 *Mitotic rate: 1 *Total Nottingham Score: 4 Histologic Grade, Traditional: Well differentiated Histologic Features DCIS: *Growth pattern: cribriform (both foci)  *Nuclear grade: Intermediate (surrounding previous biopsy site) and low (lower central focus) *Necrosis: present There's the Nottingham Histologic Score used in my report, then there's the Bloom-Richardson grade, Scarff-Bloom-Richardson grade, or Elston-Ellis grade used on cancer.org. Anyone understand this? I'm thinking the IDC is actually a grade 1 and not a 2. Thanks so much, Mindy Dx 7/21/2010, IDC, Right, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/29/2010 Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Hormonal Therapy 10/15/2010 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 3/2/2011 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What is the grade of my tumor? Halah lago

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 01:46PM Halah wrote: I hadn't thought of scar revision. I want to lose weight before any other surgery to fix other "issues" resulting from my BMX. I have these "boobs" under my arms. Many thanks for the freebies from my BS, yuk. I'm hoping to gain full range of motion but still working on it. it also seems like the scars are too high in the center! he cut from center down to the sides insted of top side down or straight across. Really messes with what necklines you can wear, or any of my old clothes I will be able to wear again. It really sucks.
Posts.Title: Scars Halah loonlover

Posts.Content: Halah wrote: Sometimes I feel almost normal (I am almost 4 weeks out as of this writing). Other times my scars feel like my nipples contracted like when you are cold. But I think when I am cold now, the area where my scars are, do sort of get tight (contract like nipples). I also notice that when I do the exercises off of the American Cancer Society's site (Exercises After Breast Surgery), my scars feel tight also. I suppose it's the muscles involved. My BS had a PS close up and hopefully I will have a thin line for scars. But only time will tell. One side is perfect but the other got kind of bunched up (not flat) so it is and will look very bad. So how are your scars doing? Are you satisfied? How are you doing with them both emotionally and physically? Posts.Title: No bps/needles in arms...what to do in surgery cinnamonsmiles Sher

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 12:07PM - edited Oct 13, 2011 12:13PM by Halah I had a colonoscopy last December and they tried to start an IV near my collarbone (I think). But they couldn't get a vein. I can't get IVs in my feet or ankles because I am diabetic. My ONC when talking about blood draws says, "ya gotta do what ya gotta do" so I get them on my left side (I am right handed). Also, my PCP insists (!) on taking my BP on my arm so I get it on my left side. When my BP is taken on my calf, the reading is always higher. So I personally am also concerned with high BP and want to know what it truly is. It seems useless to take BP on calf! I ask them to wait until I've been off my feet but they don't listen.
Posts.Title: No bps/needles in arms...what to do in surgery cinnamonsmiles Sher

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 09:38PM Halah wrote: I am very  busty yes (DD). I would like the same thing: to return to a prepubescent chest. I do have an appointment with a PS on Friday and was wondering if I should cancel or not. So I think I will keep the appointment. Also sent a message to my surgical onco with the link I provided in my initial post to see if he could do that or not and asked for him to call me. So we'll see. I can't wait until this is all over with! There's a part of me that will miss having boobs, then another part of me that experienced problems for being so busty so the BMX will solve these problems (ie. neck/back pain, they get in the way of everything lol). But the very most important part is to get the cancer out of my body! Thanks Lisa and Abby! :)
Posts.Title: A need for a PS? Halah chele

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 10:45PM Halah wrote: I just had an idea. Since I am having difficulty in making any decisions, I will call the social worker tomorrow in the Infusion department at the clinic. I'll tell her my story and see what she thinks. But I just hate having to deal with one more doctor with additional followups. And I'm just frightened I will end up with a couple of holes where my breasts were (I am a plus size woman).
Posts.Title: A need for a PS? Halah chele

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 04:22PM Halah wrote: I just talked to my surgical onco and he said the only thing my insurance would cover with PS is if I got implants. He said that most people have to deal with fat on the  back and the sides and opt for reconstruction. I told him I will not be getting a reconstruction and then I cancelled the PS. I am afraid I might be sorry later because I am a heavy woman but plan on losing weight (lost 18lbs so far) so don't know how god awful I will look after surgery. I hope I am making the right decision. But I just can't afford revisions, complications, multiple doctor followups, etc., etc... Oh god...
Posts.Title: A need for a PS? Halah chele

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 10:54PM Halah wrote: Hi Lola,  I can understand the need for rads but chemo? Did they say for sure you would need chemo? If not,  I wouldn't worry about it until you or if you get to that point in the road. It's an awful lot to take in I know. Take it slow, one step at a time. Everything you mention about your cancer is all good! It's very treatable. Give yourself permission to be thankful and positive! You might see if your husband can get counseling on this. You need him more now than ever I am sure. You are the one with cancer. But he needs help. I hope he can find peace in all of this. And you as well. You can be hopeful! Keep posting and we are here to listen. Hugs to you. Mindy
Posts.Title: Feelings lola12 hopefulhealing

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 04:54PM Halah wrote: I like to use the date of dx because I have been living with cancer since the day of dx. I had surgery on 8/30/2010 so I am NED but not cured. NED is a milestone but the cancer was there before that. Anyways that is how I count it.
Posts.Title: Survivor- How to count the years? Tabatha00 Raj20

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 07:23PM Halah wrote: I suppose y'all are right. IDK... It's just that the PET scan cost me $300 co-pay and I don't have the money. The CT and MRI cost $125 each. And the co-pay for the hospital visit will be $250. Then there's the nursing costs since I will be dealing with this by myself and live alone."Don't worry about the money, just worry about getting well", they tell me. Easy to say, difficult to swallow. I suppose I resent the doctor for ordering all those tests and wonder, what the hell! If having cancer is going to effect quality of life for the short term, and fixing cancer is going to effect the quality of life for the long haul.... hell! Sorry but I am just so blown away by all of this. I hope it's all worth it.

I highly recommend it. Good luck to you! Hang in there, it does get easier. Mindy xxx

Posts.Title: What ?'s should I ask surgeon tomorrow? Halah Halah

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 04:55AM Halah wrote: I agree with much of what the other ladies have already said. My apologies for any repeticious questions or comments here. I do think you need a second opinion though. It can only help and won't hurt a thing. Not sure what a mastologist is. I saw a surgical oncologist who did all the testing (mri, ct, bone scan, pet scan, etc.) My surgeon referred me to a plastic surgeon and I saw him, and this doctor was responsible for his part. Is her surgeon talking about all of it? Or is he sending her to other specialists? How can he know chemo if she hasn't yet had surgery and the extent of the surgery? What, no lymph nodes affected? That is great! Medical ONC usually talks about treatments such as chemo, NOT the surgeon. My surgeon left it up to me as to whether or not to get my healthy breast removed. It shouldn't be the doctor's decision! It's your mother's body! It seems to me the biopsies need to be done prior to surgery to see what exactly needs to be done, unless you're talking about the lymph nodes of course. Were there any biopsies done on the tumor? What is the diagnosis? Sorry for so many questions. I am just trying to understand and to be of some help, hopefully. Mindy

My BS is a surgical oncologist specializing in breast surgery. Instead of disliking him for taking my breasts, I suppose I ought to be thanking him for NED. But I don't know if that is the real reason I don't like him. I just don't like how I look. I feel he could have done a better job in that area.
Posts.Title: Follow up with surgeon for 5 years? Why? Halah Mantra

Posts.Content: Halah wrote: I was dx 2 weeks 5 days ago and it has certainly been a roller coaster ride. I've been scared to death and have feared the worst for my health and financial well being. I am beginning to believe that my BS ordered way too many tests and now have a big fat bill. If your cancer is caught early and a lymph node survey is done via ultrasound, and the doctor has poked around and doesn't find anything, what tests do you think would have been necessary at a maximum? I've had a bone scan, MRI of both breasts, mammo of healthy breast, CT, and PET Scan. the bone scan found what was believed to have been lesions on my skull and rib cage but it was not cancer. The doc says "well I guess that's just how your bones are". hell! i went through hell! I bring this up because of a flyer I received in a package today that the susan g. komen org sent me. It's about the lymphatic system. It seems to me that if my cancer was caught early, I should have just been wheeled into surgery and have auxillary nodes removed from levels 1 and 2 to see if the cancer had spread. Why the need for all the tests? Thanks, Mindy Dx 7/21/2010, IDC, Right, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/29/2010 Lymph node removal: Left, Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Hormonal Therapy 10/15/2010 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 3/2/2011 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: To test or not to test? Halah LizM

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 07:39PM Halah wrote: My clinic set up a payment plan before the PET scan (made me pay $100 before the test which went on my credit card). The payment they agreed to was $45/month not based on what I could pay, but based on what they accepted. If I don't pay it then it goes to collections. And I asked them if it will effect my credit they said yes. I am on SSDI (disability) and they know this. I don't know why they didn't do more tests for you, Amy. My cancer was caught early during a followup mammo. This is why I wonder why they did so much for me. I wish these doctors would get on the same page and stick to what is medically necessary, either way!
Posts.Title: To test or not to test? Halah LizM

Posts.Content: Halah wrote: Are they telling you that you need to follow up with your surgeon on a regular basis for 5 years? My surgeon told me I need to see him every 6 months for 5 years for an examination. Why? Can't exams be done by a GP or a GYN or even the ONC? Also, how often are they telling you you need to see your ONC for follow up? What is your experience? Personally I don't see the value in the surgeon doing the exam. A surgeon cuts. And I don't like him. Don't get me wrong, I certainly want to do all I can to avoid a recurrence. I can understand why the ONC, I just don't understand why the surgeon. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 05:25AM Halah wrote: Annie, thank you so much for your kind words. Although I have yet to see an onco, and although I'm thinking there is no cure, I do really feel somewhat hopeful after having gone through this thread. At the same time, I get the idea that it ain't over yet. But I MUST take a vacation away from all of this and just do something that I wouldn't ordinarily do (no I won't go rob a bank lol). A friend of mine and I are going to this nature sactuary near where we live tomorrow. It's gotten cool here in Houston and it is just wonderful. I'm also working on how I think and how denial can be a good thing if one remains smart about it (like saying I'm cancer free yet still go see my onco, smart like that). My head might say one thing, but I will allow my heart to say another which hopefully will influence my head. Something like that anyways. And perhaps taking that approach I'll be okay. But I really like my new role of Valkyrie Warrior Goddess!!!! LOL

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 11:03AM Halah wrote: I didn't mean to be such a downer, it really isn't as hard as it sounds. Once you get it done, you will have this huge sense of relief and the fear and anxiety is gone! It's all doable. I opted no reconstruction because it would entail more dr visits and possibly more surgeries to fix potential problems thus the copays. I have limited funds. I didn't know it at the time but I did need a PS in the beginning because of the dog ears. Now I need more surgery to fix this, thus more dr visits thus the hospital copay. I am scheduled for surgery on Mar 3rd for this revision. Oh well, PS it is. Not reconstruction btw. Reconstruction is a personal thing. Check out the two forums, one for going breast free and the other for reconstruction. You can get better answers from these ladies. You both are in my thoughts! Mindy xxx

Glad to meet you but wish it were under other circumstances.
Posts.Title: PET Scan nurseronda10 in_cognito

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 07:26PM Halah wrote: I would think it would depend on where you got the tests and who your doctor is. I go to a city wide clinic and all the diagnostics are done there and all my medical professionals are there. All the locations are connected via computer so they can get the results almost instantly in some cases, like I got my mammo one hour and was available to the doc the next hour.  It will all get straightened out I am sure. I would talk to your doctor.
Posts.Title: Can't handle the wait; Tech gave me my scans calamtykel tryn2staycalm

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 10:44PM Halah wrote: Hello ladies! I am Mindy and was in your shoes last August. That's 5 months out from a BMX no recon, and you will be 5 months out in no time, too! The waiting is the worst part because of the unknown. Once you've had your surgery, it will be much better. The drains weren't anything more than an inconvenience for me. I pinned mine onto my shirts with safety pins. You can also use a lanyard to pin them on. You can find the wedge pillows at bed bath & beyond, or any medical supply store. Y'all be sure to read up on the shopping thread in this forum as it really made me think of things I never would have thought of otherwise. Best to you all! Mindy xxx
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 12:55AM Halah wrote: Hi Maria, My dx was at 50 and is idc <1cm, grade 1, ER/PR+ HER2-, no node involvement, and with a 16 for the oncotype dx test and opted for no chemo. I had no idea that metformin decreased risk for breast cancer recurrence. I take that for diabetes and I am glad to hear this. Jo1955, with regards to getting the test done...I have good stats and questioned the same thing. The oncotype dx test result can change everything and from what I have learned it is an important test to be taken. Mindy xxx
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 02:18AM Halah wrote: Although I had  one "healthy" breast, I chose a BMX and my insurance paid for it as well. As it turned out, both breasts had atypical lobular hyperplasia which can (usually?) develop into cancer. So as you can see, it was the best outcome for me. Maria! Good to "see" you! Glad to hear you are doing so well. :) But wow, did you have trouble with nausea or what? When I woke up in recovery, I was in the middle of throwing up and feared I was choking. But after that no nausea. After they wheeled me to a room, I was actually feeling happy because of all the pain medicine and the wonderful cup of coffee I finally got after a long morning of waiting for surgery. I had trouble getting in and out of bed because the bed was too high. I only stayed the one night. Once I got home, I went to the dining room for supper (I live in a retirement community). Am I crazy or what. After that I was out like a light for a couple days.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 01:46PM Halah wrote: I started a similar thread as this, and many women said if you have the opportunity to do chemo, "then do it". It's like having an additional insurance policy to just tamoxofin alone. If I had kids, perhaps I'd had chemo (my test score was 16). I had a low grade tumor and all the other variables were good (if you want to call cancer "good"). Glad you found this onc!! I agree, she's a keeper. :)

Posts.Title: Remission or "cured"? Halah wobbly

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 10:41AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 07:20PM by Halah I am the original poster of this thread in search for the truth. I wanted to know, I needed to know. I value every single post and have been listening intently. But now, it is obvious to me that there is no cure for breast cancer. I'm just being real with myself in saying this. There's no way for me to know for myself that I won't have a recurrence. But it looks good for me that I will not. It saddens me to know it won't be the case for other sisters here. I will be hypervigilant with my cancer. After all, I could still have a recurrence if I am not mindful of it. And I will add a healthy dose of denial. Why? A social worker once told me "denial is okay" In other words, she was telling me to think that planes don't fly into buildings. It was a way of denying something I couldn't change, thus eliminating some of the anxiety that went with it. I will try and live my life without the fear of recurrence, and shoot for NED. That's all I can do. I don't know what more I can do. Since my dx on 7/21/2010, I started wearing this pink band that said, "say it - fight it - cure it". Wearing it in the beginning helped a LOT. But now, not so much. I took it off today. I need no reminders that I have cancer. Be mindful of it? Yes. Daily reminders? No.

So I find myself not testing at all. NOT good. I'm just so ticked off that I had to get diabetes and then BC. Now I have to worry about LE. It's all more than I can handle and to hell with it all.

Posts.Title: diabetic/pricking finger Halah Halah

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 09:55PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:59AM by Halah I no longer use the lancet device. I just take a lancet and poke myself several times at the same spot until I can draw blood. Then I can get a reading. Unfortunately it doesn't stop bleeding as easily like when you prick your finger so I use one of those small circular clear bandaids for the spot I poked. I do this on my thigh which seems more convenient as I don't want bandaids to be seen on my calves. I'd get a port for the chemo. I hear the power port is good for everything like chemo, rads, and drawing blood. Ask your doctor about that. Good luck. Mindy :)

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 10:41AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:56AM by Halah I have been trying to figure this out, thus the delay in my reply. I don't get any blood from my thigh or my calf. So I called the makers of my glucose meter and they have no other lancet device except for alternate sites being the palm or the forearm. I did try and take a lancet (without any device) and poke myself multiple times in the same site but gosh, that's horrible! I'm thinking my toes. Haven't tried that yet. When I asked my GP about alternate sites, he wants to see me to see my arms??? Asked the nurse why, because I can't use my arms!! Golly gee wiz, it sounds so simple. So using my fingertips would really put me at risk for lymphedema?

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 11:36PM - edited Jan 25, 2011 11:38PM by Halah Hi Jackie, When is your surgery? The waiting is killer. But it will all be over with in no time! They had me arrive two hours early (time stood still) and obviously no coffee before surgery. After surgery I was dying for a caffeine fix. I was walking the halls that evening in the hospital and couldn't sleep. The bed was too high to get in and out of. The PS closed me up and glued me shut. I had this burning sensation where my breasts were. There will be numbness and you will lose range of motion. My range of motion is pretty much improved but not at 100%, and I still have some numbness in places. I had four drains. Not sure if you know about these. The drains capture the fluid that builds up after surgery. You're supposed to empty the drains at regular intervals for a few days. They are a pain but time goes by quickly. I experienced a loss after losing my breasts. Surgeons must either be loved (no cancer!) or hated (no breasts!). I think my surgeon is afraid of me lol. Check out the surgery forum. There is a thread about a shopping list and how to prepare. I would have been lost without that thread. And also in that forum, there's usually a thread dedicated for each month for women who are having surgery in the respective month. You'll find many friends and support there. It's doable. You'll be okay!  Mindy xxx

Pretty dramatic idea I know, but I am at my wit's end. Seems easier to just give up.

Posts.Title: Why not just keep the breast? Halah dlb823

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 02:02PM - edited Aug 19, 2010 02:07PM by Halah I have decided to go ahead with the surgery. I saw a medical oncologist and the only option at this point is surgery. It was such a difficult thing to accept! A lumpectomy is not an option. So since I am a DD, I'm getting a BMX. Being big busted makes it difficult to keep one and attempt to look normal with either implants later or breast forms. In my mind, it's both or nothing. Also saw a social worker in the infusion department and she was a tremendous help as well. The onco said I would at least be treated with tamoxofen or the generic of arimidex for up to 5 years after surgery (I don't have to pay for generics). My psychopathic father said he'd pay my bills for me and I am checking it out every day to see if the clinic received the payment. I hate that I have to ask him for help because he is so mean (there's a history there). But if I can just get through this surgery then perhaps everything will be okay.
Posts.Title: Why not just keep the breast? Halah dlb823

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 06:49PM Halah wrote: Cathy, my MD called me on the telephone to tell me I had cancer and what it was. Call your doctor and talk to him/her on the phone, because to wait a week is really unfair. Good luck to you. Mindy xxx
Posts.Title: I got the phone call, now I'm in a panic dreidteacher irish22

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 02:29PM Halah wrote: Hi Kristy, I had surgery on August 30th. I had one drain fall out 6 days out and another 7 days out. It didn't hurt when that happened but it really made a mess. (The stuff really smells and is gross.) So now I have this sloshing that I hear on the left side where the drains were. Not sure if the surgeon will aspirate the fluid or not. Today is 16 days out and I still have the two drains on my right side. I'm still putting out 20cc more or less so I think I am ready! I see my surgeon on Friday. If he wants to leave them in any longer, the answer is NO!! It's my body so it's up to me AFAIC. Anyways, I think it will be more freeing without the drains; you're limited with them being there. They get in the way, are annoying, etc. One thing that helps me: get a lanyard. I use that when I change tops or bathe. You'll need something to attach the bulbs to when you're not wearing anything. I also use the lanyard when I go to the doc which makes it easier for the examination.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 12:30PM Halah wrote: gutsy, gosh it seems like just yesterday you posted about your surgery.  I'm sorry you're needing more. Whether or not you do reconstruction at the same time of the MX is a personal decision. I will have  a BMX and opted for no recon at this time because if i need radiation afterwards, it could have negative effects on implants. I'd hate to have to need even more surgery! But who knows, I just might remain breast free and get breast forms and still look girly. It's a personal thing. I'm getting a BMX because I am DD and they don't make implants or breast forms that size from what I've read. I also don't want to risk the chance of recurrence. But good luck to you! It always works out in the end! You'll get through this.
